name: Temptation Creek Trail
text: I did the loop that goes from 159 Farnell Avenue, via Loftus Loop Track and Temptation Creek. The trail was amazing! You can even walk all the way up to the waterfall. Once you get all the way down, just before you start the ascent there is a stream of water that goes in the middle of the path. If you're coming through the Loftus Loop track side, before you cross this stream, on your right is a small opening that leads upwards. Follow this trail up and you will be able to see the little waterfall. Quite the view!! If it had rained the previous couple of days, the track can be pretty boggy so I highly suggest wearing waterproof boots if this is the case.

name: Xanthorrhoea Trail
text:
As usual this is an unmarked trail. Definitely download the map because there are multiple places where paths overlap and you will probably get horribly lost.
Despite that, this is probably one of the best near-Perth walks to do. It has some very steep sections at the start and finish to really test you, and gentle and moderate sections. Most of the time the paths are very easy to follow, although there are a few narrow parts. Given the recent rain the paths are muddy in places, but not terrible. Water is flowing in all the gullies and creeks, which provides a beautiful soundscape, as do the many different bird songs. The views across the flood plain to Perth are glorious as are the views to the hills.
If you enjoy being challenged without being smashed, this is a great walk.

name: You Yangs Regional Park
text:
Located just 30 minutes from Geelong, this family-friendly hiking destination is one of nature's gems. It's a perfect spot for outdoor enthusiasts of all ages.

The area offers several hiking tracks, each with its own unique features. Whether you choose a single trail or explore them all, you're in for a treat. Upon arrival, you'll find an information center on the left, equipped with restrooms and helpful maps to guide your adventure.

This location is also popular for family barbecues and picnics. The well-maintained facilities and scenic surroundings make it an ideal spot for a day out with loved ones. However, be sure to bring a warm coat if you're visiting in winter, as it can get quite chilly when the sun sets.

Overall, this hiking destination is a wonderful escape into nature, providing a variety of activities and beautiful landscapes just a short drive from the city.

Here the second segment of the Great North Walk (Berowra Valley National Park) starts.

I did Thornleigh --> Hornsby Heights 21km 7h45 (moving time 6h45), challenging.

When you reach the Fishpond Lookout, I suggest you keep going on the former Great North to reach the Fishpond; then go back and follow the deviation to Manor Rd.

The trail is well maintained and marked but it is a ‚Äúnatural‚Äù path so full of rocks and roots. You should use a trail app to be sure you're on the right way.

I found the most uneven path on my way down (pretty steep especially on the way down in Galston Gorge with a few climbing spikes as well; instead, the ways up have mainly proper steps) so I guess you should choose the route according to this.

The first segment of the way out in Hornsby Heights is not an official path and is not signaled so keep an eye on your map; however after about 300m it becomes a fire trail easy to follow.

The 596 bus brings you to the train station.

No toilets and no drinking water on the whole way.

I‚Äôm not an expert hiker and not even a sportive person but I did it, so I guess the trail is for everyone.

name: Elouera Bushland Natural Park
text:
This can be a nice short walk about 30 to 45 mins return starting from Westwood Street, Pennant Hills.

Walk to the end of Westwood St, there is a flight of stairs down towards Dale Close.At the bottom of the stars, turn left and walk to the Cul De Sac. Go into the track marked Eluoera Bushland Natural Parkon your right.

Walk past the little Creek and follow the track to the Zig Zag bridge.

Go up the steep slope and you'll see the Quarry on the right. If you are adventurous, you can climb up the steep cliff around the quarry. Otherwise go up the flight of stairs further down past the quarry.

Return to Westwood Street by retracing your steps.

For a longer walk, follow the Great North Walk track from the Zig Zag bridge towards the Jungo, formerly an aboriginal meeting place.

name: Albert Park Walking Track
text: If you visit to Melbourne city, taking a walk in the evening about sunset time to Albert park is a must. The views of reflection of the city on the water is amazing and the golden hour hits different. The bushes, palm trees and the ducks adds all the difference and is very relaxing and peaceful. name: Florence Parade Trail
text: I love hiking in this area, the tracks are plentiful, and you get to walk along a river (you can choose which one, depending on the track you want to follow). So far I've come back twice and still haven't explored nearly even half of the available tracks. I usually start near Grays Point public school, and there's usually plenty of car spots there, so parking is not hard. Some tracks can be easy, some can be more challenging, I think there's one that suits everyone. But unlike in the Blue Mountains for example, this one don't have the information board to help you choose the tracks on-site, so you have to research a bit using your phone (Google Maps).

name: Florence Parade Trail
text: Lots of different trail options and beautiful bush views

name: Florence Parade Trail
text: My absolute favourite local trail run or walk when I lived in the area.  Highly recommended midweek daytime to have the entire trail to yourself.  Grays Point Road is a good parking/start/finish point for a fabulous 16km.  Give yourself 2 hours to run or 4 hours to walk.  Not even a Telstra signal from just after Engadine until half way up Honeymoon (going anticlockwise), have a survival strategy - you can run without water and first aid but not recommended for most people.  Wear safety specs if running through the tight Engadine - Audley section, check for bush fires.  Both directions have benefits so I alternate.  You will need a national parks pass if parking in the park (annual pass is best).

name: Glenthorne National Park ‚Äî Ityamaiitpinna Yarta
text:
We visited Glenthorne on a whim, after driving around and randomly exploring Adelaide and its surrounds.

We had no idea what to expect so went in blind, but ended up loving the hour or so we spent there. The park proudly embraces indigenous culture, informs and educates about the local flora and fauna, and contains an awesome playground/BBQ area for families and kids, as well as offering walking tracks through the grounds.

Usually, when I see the very typical dry and barren Aussie grasslands, I'm not too enthused. On this occasion, however, being in the midst of it and away from society (to a reasonable extent, anyway), it was surprisingly peaceful and serene. I could have sat on a rock for hours, just watching the birds and enjoying the sunshine.

The playground is truly one-of-a-kind and would have been a regular haunt had my kids grown up in the area. Everything is a clever blend of steel and timber, giving it a very colonial, 'this belongs here' feel. I was very impressed. For the parents, there's some covered seating, clean toilets, and the aforementioned BBQs. And, should seating be limited on a busy day, the ample shady trees can help you out.

Overall, Glenthorne NP was a lucky find. It gave us an unexpected detox from the hustle-and-bustle, and I say that with a certain level of mirth, considering we were in Adelaide enjoying a holiday! Nevertheless, peace and quiet is always a good thing, as is swapping people for animals, now and again. Glenthorne is a lovely spot, please see it for yourself when the timing and weather suits.

name: Glen Stewart Park
text:
Nestled in the heart of nature‚Äôs embrace, Glen Stewart Park is a breathtaking escape from the bustling city life. My visits throughout the seasons have allowed me to capture its ever-changing yet always enchanting beauty.

In the warmth of summer, the lush canopy of leaves provides a verdant backdrop to the winding trails and the wooden bridge that serves as a charming gateway to tranquility. The sunlight filters through the branches, painting patterns of light and shadow that dance upon the path.

As autumn arrives, the park dons a golden cloak. The crisp air carries the rustle of fallen leaves, and the forest floor becomes a carpet of amber hues. The stark, bare branches of winter reveal the park's stoic grace under a blanket of snow, transforming the landscape into a monochrome masterpiece. The bridge, now dusted with snow, stands as a steadfast sentinel overseeing the quiet stillness.

Come spring, a chorus of birdsong heralds the rebirth of the park. Buds peek through the branches, and the gentle flow of the stream sings a melody of renewal.

For those seeking a momentary retreat or a peaceful hike, Glen Stewart Park is not just a destination; it‚Äôs an experience that lingers in the heart long after one's footsteps have left its grounds.

name: Glen Stewart Park
text: Beautiful, well-maintained park. Different experiences depending on the season and I recommend both summer and winter. name: North Table Mountain Park West Trailhead

I highly recommend spending a few hours exploring the area.

name: Apex Park
text: Amazing place to go for a little ride! The main loop was about 9 miles with 2000‚Äô if climbing. Odd days have one way trails for bikes which is nice for climbing consistently on Apex trail! Going back again next weekend!

name: Apex Park
text: Lovely park with lots of hikes! Can‚Äôt wait to come back.

name: Apex Park
text: Went on July 4th, started about 8:30. Trail starting out is sunny, parts are shaded, little creek follows you up the trail. We took Apex to Enchanted Forest and came back around the loop to Apex Trail. Enchanted Forest was beautiful, much cooler with all the trees, path opens up a bit more. Odd days are best for hikers as mountain bikers are limited to one way only. We encountered a lot of mountain bikers as yesterday was an even day, however all were courteous. Saw tons of wildlife, everything was really green with flowers everywhere. Trail imo is more difficult in the beginning as there are lots of rocks to climb over, but still doable. Bring lots of water, no water at all on the trail, only restrooms are in the parking lot (very clean though) Have fun and enjoy our states beauty.

name: Vista Trail Trailhead, Rouge National Urban Park
text:
We went out hiking at sunrise. It was nice a quiet and the air was brisk. Earlier in the walk we saw deer. The route was clear and an easy trail to walk.
We took the Vista and Mast route. There are a lot of side trails that are fun to explore if you are curious. All round nice walk great for dog walks and there is free parking too!

name: Vista Trail Trailhead, Rouge National Urban Park
text:
Plenty of space to park, but its also quite busy.
There are mobile toilets on parking lot.
The trail is about 3 km both way with some hillsides, stairs and bridges.
Not suitable for the stroller. Would not recommend bike either - it‚Äôs quite busy here.
There are only a couple of benches and picnic area only at the bottom of Orchard trail.

name: Vista Trail Trailhead, Rouge National Urban Park
text:
Nice weather and wonderful viewsüçÅ
See the leaves, feel the wind, hear the sound of the river and smell the scent of the forest‚ú®‚ú®
Recommend a walk in daytime. Easy to go, and you can start from Vista and end with Orchard trail üë£

name: Vista Trail Trailhead, Rouge National Urban Park
text: Vista Trail in Rouge National Urban Park is a perfect escape from city life, offering beautiful views of the Rouge River Valley and lush Carolinian forest. The trail is easy to navigate and great for a short, peaceful hike or walk, with an observation platform providing panoramic views, especially breathtaking in fall. The path is mostly flat, making it accessible to families and beginners, though watch for some exposed roots. Parking can get busy, so arriving early is a good idea. Highly recommended for anyone in the Toronto area looking for a quick nature retreat close to the city

name: Vista Trail Trailhead, Rouge National Urban Park
text: Very nice trail to go with your beloved ones! Probably it‚Äôs the best timing to see the fall colors! It‚Äôs not all red yet but very colorful! We did the Vista trail plus the Orchard trail, 8+ kms, 2+ hours. Quite busy on weekends. But the further you go, the fewer people you see! You‚Äôll go through up and down hills and some of them are steep so safety first!

name: North Cheyenne Ca√±on Park
text: Absolute hidden Gem üíé! I‚Äôm surprised no one has really reviewed this area. If you are new I would highly recommend the Lower and medium columbine trails! We took the medium columbine trail up to Tunnel 1 and it was definitely worth the hike! Lots of üå≥s and we even saw a ü¶å!

name: North Cheyenne Ca√±on Park
text: It's all uphill but the scenery will keep you going and your heart pumping! Steep edges, be careful and you should not be afraid of heights.

name: North Cheyenne Ca√±on Park
text: Tons of great hiking trails for all levels of experience. Beautiful views, waterfalls and flowing cascades. Nice, shaded trails.

name: North Cheyenne Ca√±on Park
text: Beautiful area.went and got engagement photos done there.  But our friends we were with there car got robbed. Someone stole their wallet and purse! Be cautious. Isn‚Äôt the first time this has happened there. (First time to them)

name: North Cheyenne Ca√±on Park
text: My favorite place to hike....

name: Weir Gulch Park
text: I've lived by this place my whole life and this park is really extensive and fun to bring the kids for a bike ride. this is a really good park if you want to explore or if you just want to play basketball or use a playground because if you follow the creek westwards from I-25 you will stumble on many different playgrounds and picnic areas that are perfect for spending more time with your family.

name: Weir Gulch Park
text: Nice place to sit for a while, let kids run around and play. Playground is a little worn out, hope they build a new one soon for the children. Little river going all the way through the park, beware of mosquitoes.

name: Weir Gulch Park
text: Beautiful park with paved trail alongside the South Platte. Lots of geese poop along the way but an otherwise wonderful walking and biking path.

name: Weir Gulch Park
text: This little park would be much better if something was done about the geese population. There was geese feces everywhere that made it difficult to walk and to sit.

name: Weir Gulch Park
text: Nice trail that I could walk the dogs. So many plants near the trail!

name: Wagon Trail Park
text: Nice clean park with a fun playground. If they had the giant swirl slide of the old days I would give a 5th star.

name: Wagon Trail Park
text: Clean and Brand-new.  No more purple slide. Very cool modern space-ship-looking jungle gym. My kiddos really love this park.

name: Wagon Trail Park
text: The taco bar is top notch

name: Wagon Trail Park
text: It was quiet, nobody around bothering you or cops trolling. Really beautiful and peaceful

name: Wagon Trail Park
text: We live in the neighborhood and have enjoyed this park for years. They recently updated some equipment and the open area is great. Nice city views on a clear day.

name: Swallow Trail Parking
text:
A few trails around here.  I just came for a brief walk during lunch.  Plenty of parking,  also have a building for seperate restrooms.   There are a few picnic tables above the parking lot, and also the trails themselves.
The views are gorgeous.   There are plenty of red sandstone formations.   These are fenced off, so no climbing them.  It's a really cool area!

name: Swallow Trail Parking
text: Great place to enjoy God's creation and hike along an easy Trail!

name: Swallow Trail Parking
text: Good hike, not a lot of elevation changes, hike up Lyons Back trail for a good view

name: Swallow Trail Parking
text: Perfect place for short easy hikes or moderately long hikes. Dog friendly.

name: Swallow Trail Parking
text: Beautiful place and a great area to meet up with friends

name: Trading Post Trail
text: Nice quick trail about 1.5 miles long and mostly flat with just a big hill at the end. Trail is clearly marked but there was no shade for the duration of the trail so even though it's easy definitely bring a lot of water in the heat. Lots of pretty rock formations right on the trail. Free parking at the trading post building was nice!

name: Trading Post Trail
text: Strongly recommend doing the trail if you got like an hour here, it leads up back up to the concert/visitor center area. It‚Äôs easy and scenic without being overly crowded. You could definitely run it within 30minutes as well!

name: Trading Post Trail
text: A very good trail located on the Red Rocks Park and Amphitheater grounds. Approximately 1.5 Mi long, but you gain almost 400 ft in elevation. Parts of the trail are actually flat steps (pic) that can be rather slippery if you're not paying attention- and especially on your way down as you might be moving faster. Just be careful and you'll be fine. My wife and I are 69 years old when we did this trail 4 weeks ago and we did just fine. The scenery and wildlife in the area is just spectacular.

name: Trading Post Trail
text: Appropriate that we had to wander around out there seeing Lord Huron at Red Rocks.  Steep, but beautiful.  Even at night.

name: Trading Post Trail
text: This is my favorite trail to take out-of-state visitors on because it is not too long or super steep but still offers beautiful scenery.

name: Moore Park Ravine
text: It is a really nice trail/loop. Best for warm days as there‚Äôs tons of natural shade. Some of the trail is closed off for construction but it‚Äôs still worth a hike.

name: Moore Park Ravine
text: Amazing trail if you wanna go for a run or have a relaxing walk..

name: Moore Park Ravine
text: Came here when I was like 10 and it was  unpaved. Such a difference! Love it so multi purpose & the view from the bottom and the architecture seen from below was incredible

name: Moore Park Ravine
text: Discover the scenic 6.1-km loop trail, an accessible route with an average completion time of 1 hour and 23 minutes. Ideal for hiking and mountain biking.

name: Moore Park Ravine
text: Beautiful trail but lots of people.  Best to go in the fall when all the leaves are changing color.  You can also access Evergreen Brickworks from this trail and go up to Chorly Park.  It's a very long trail so you could spend an entire day walking it.

name: Daniels Gate Trail Parking
text: This is definitely a great little hike for the family and pets. While it is heavily trafficked it still offers an escape and quick exercise.  Bathrooms are very clean and the trails are well maintained.  All the closed off fencing was bothersome and took away from the full experience but overall it was still a good hike

name: Daniels Gate Trail Parking
text: Beautiful park to run, bike, hike, etc. Not much shade though. Main Trail seems to be stroller friendly as well. Mostly rolling hills for about 4 miles through the park. A few places to park inside the park and on the outskirts of the park. Beautiful scenery!

name: Daniels Gate Trail Parking
text: Beautiful place to take pictures!

name: Daniels Gate Trail Parking
text: Coolest place to park and enjoy the view,  and great place to launch a drone!

name: Daniels Gate Trail Parking
text: So scenic. If you're lucky, you'll see the bison roaming around.

name: Fox Run Regional Park
text: I always love to come here regardless of the time of year. Have been coming here for almost 20 years now. It‚Äôs a nice large park with a couple small pounds to walk around. The perimeter of the park is just about a 5k and is what I use to as a running area. There is always plenty of parking and room to be alone in the ‚Äúwoods‚Äù. Everyone should come check this place out! Defently recommend bring you hammock.

name: Fox Run Regional Park
text: Great park. We took a group of 72 students/leaders here to enjoy a lunch break and we all really enjoyed it. We were in town from Texas to attend the awesome, life-changing Desperation Conference at New Life Church. It was a bummer that the volleyball nets weren't available and only porta potties for restrooms.

name: Fox Run Regional Park
text:
The park was very nice.  We were there for a wedding ceremony in the wedding gazebo and then the reception in a different area. The park gave no indication, via signs,  of where anything could be located.  Guests drove around searching for the gazebo then again to find the reception with numbers marking gathering sites in no particular order.
The plan was to dress for the wedding, then to change into casual clothing for outdoor games, etc. The large bathrooms were all locked, in the middle of June!! The only option was to use the porta-potty! That is not ever a good option, and even worse when one is all dressed up. Everything would have been much smoother with available bathroom availability.

name: Fox Run Regional Park
text:
Great, big park with wide open spaces and clean places!
Beautifully maintained area with an updated playground that has fun colors and safe low-to-the-ground features, has gazebos, even a wedding gazebo, picnic pavilions with tables that are kept clean, dog park, horseback riding, volleyball, 4 miles of hiking trails, a horseshoe pit, water fountains and big, clean restrooms, But beware of the compostable toilets they have as anything that goes down, will not be easily retrieved!!
All facilities are able to be reserved. We enjoyed the park during a company picnic where a petting zoo was able to be brought in, a bounce house, food vendor, corn hole set up and made use of the volleyball set up.
Plenty of parking and good signage for figuring out which pavilion you need to go to or other attractions you may be trying to get to as you enter the park.
Lots of rolling hills and healthy trees that provide natural shade. Nice open fields for playing catch, football, or soccer. For dogs, the grass is well maintained and dog park is kept clean.
We look forward to going back and spending more time there and enjoying the pavilions with water features.

name: Fox Run Regional Park
text:
Recently renovated ( last year or so -ish ), great for anything you want to do outsideAlways great. Go to the bathroom before you go to the park in the winter though, the bathrooms are closed for the season. Weddings, parties, reunions, hiking, biking, multiple playgrounds, private forest picnic tables, you name it! This place is perfect for it!

We always rent a pavilion and have our kids birthday parties here ü•∞üéâüíï‚òÄÔ∏è

name: Clear Creek Trail
text: This is a highly recommended trail. It is comfortably organized so it does not get too busy (especially early in the morning), there are shaded spots, and the maintenance is fabulous. Along the trail there are spots for tubing, carefully going into the water or just quietly sitting by them. The golden history park situated by the trail is also very interesting and highly recommended. The trail is right downtown so you can enjoy nature and find a good place to eat right thereafter.

name: Clear Creek Trail
text:
One of the main attractions for Golden. Plenty of sport and fun to be found in and around the creek off this trail. Or just a beautiful walk no matter the season. Also always good for people watching if that‚Äôs your thing. There are plenty of benches all along the path. If you walk the north side you can get to many of the main places in Golden: Parfet park, lions park, the library, the tennis courts, the baseball fields, RV/camping park, and a lot of Golden history including the Golden History Museum.

If you like to bike, the south side of the trail is for you. Not too bad of a ride.

name: Clear Creek Trail
text: Visited Clear Creek in the winter ‚Äì it was stunning. The snow transformed and enhanced beauty of the creek. The trail was not too crowded (came in the morning) and it offers a serene stroll along the clear, flowing water. Well-maintained and impeccably clean trail.

name: Clear Creek Trail
text: Beautiful! Such a nice hiking trail along Clear Creek. Golden is a cute little town and we had a wonderful day learning about its history and enjoying the local food. Will definitely be back and hopefully get to go tubing down the creek!

name: Clear Creek Trail
text: Beautiful trail! Goes on for a while, has amazing views, access to the creek, and connects to many other trails along the way. I think you could spend a long time taking it all in on this trail!

name: Sondermann Park
text: It‚Äôs a pretty cool park in the middle of Colorado Springs. It‚Äôs got some really nice trails and a little river that runs through it so my son lives the walk across this little area.

name: Sondermann Park
text: The locals call it the Enchanted Forest. It's truly a place full of magic. Walking through at night is a whole different experience. At twilight, you will see strange small lights along the path and in the trees. The wildlife is most active at night. Skinny little coyotes, families of deer, and big juvenile bears come out to eat and play. There are two trees that produce edible fruits and so far I've found one bush with raspberries that are in bloom during spring.

name: Sondermann Park
text: This little park close to downtown Colorado Springs is absolutely beautiful! Lovely huge trees and colors, with a creek bubbling along the trail. The park has a small car park and playground and one trash bin. Lovely hike for the whole family!

name: Sondermann Park
text: Highly enjoyable place to hike. I definitely recommend coming here. You can bring the whole family or be on your own. There are picnic areas and the creek is absolutely beautiful. You can even ride your bike, there is plenty of room. I'll definitely make this park my go to spot.

name: Sondermann Park
text: Loved it! Well kept with panic tables and benches as well as trash bins. Staff friendly. There are many labeled trails and maps. I loved the interactive guided signs. Great scenery with plenty of wildlife. The variations of hiking biking or horseback riding is a plus. Pet and kid friendly with a play area for children.

name: Big dry creek trail
text:
Beautiful, Clean nice park for walking the dog, playing for the kids! A lot of running space and flowing CLEAR water! it‚Äôs so nice here.
I didn‚Äôt know it was a trail / park ! What else can I ask for? ü´∂üèΩüôèüèæüôåüèæ

name: Big dry creek trail
text: Lots of trails around parks, however, a lot of homeless and sketchy people around.  When I got back from my walk, I came to find out my car had been broken into.  Window smashed and my purse missing.

name: Big dry creek trail
text: This the most beautiful trail in Littleton. On summer days it can get a little bit busy but I think company is part of the experience. My family and I hike this trail at least once a month, and try to go every week if we can. Probably the best part about living in Colorado is that you get the opportunity to experience these kind of natural experiences.

name: Big dry creek trail
text: I absolutely love taking my dog on walks here! They're constantly upgrading/improving the area to be more user friendly and safe. It's along The Big Dry Creek Trail, so it's a constant battle for space between parks and rec vs. the homeless population that live along there and it's one of the few areas that parks and rec is able to take a win. I've personally never been scared or felt uncomfortable down along the trails nor at Progress Park, which anywhere in the vicinity of the Platte River, that's huge!

name: Big dry creek trail
text: Just west of Broadway entrance the trail has been turned into huge trash dump with left behind encampment garbage.

name: Backcountry Wilderness Area Wildcat Mountain Trail and Archery Range Parking
text: I had a great run at this trail. It is smooth and has beautiful views and gently rolling terrain. It is a great place to mountain bike ride as well.

name: Backcountry Wilderness Area Wildcat Mountain Trail and Archery Range Parking
text: Very nice easy/moderate trail with great views and various terrain.  The trails are kind of narrow, mostly single file.  Nonetheless, a nice place to visit.

name: Backcountry Wilderness Area Wildcat Mountain Trail and Archery Range Parking
text: This place has an amazing variety of smooth trails excellent for biking or hiking... You can shoot at the archery range from a variety of distances as well. Be careful of mountain lions and rattlesnakes...

name: Backcountry Wilderness Area Wildcat Mountain Trail and Archery Range Parking
text: Good single-track, but spend half your time looking at a large power station. Pretty dang quiet.

name: Backcountry Wilderness Area Wildcat Mountain Trail and Archery Range Parking
text: Such a great open space/back country to walk for a couple of hours (shorter loops too).

name: Runyon Canyon Park
text:
A very interesting and completely free park that goes all the way from Fuller Avenue and Vista Street up to Mulholland Drive. You can either choose to walk up from from street level via Hollywood or drive up to the entrance at the top via Mulholland.

There is a major pathway that‚Äôs paved with concrete, but there are also numerous side trails and ridge lines that split away. You can take all kinds of interesting routes to vista points and mountainside paths.

From the top part of the trail and it‚Äôs various points along canyons ridges you can most of Los Angeles. It‚Äôs a great and breathtaking view. Runyon Canyon has a lot to offer hikers of all fitness levels, and the sights are spectacular.

It‚Äôs a great getaway from the bustle of Los Angeles. You‚Äôre quite close to the city but you feel transported into nature and completely removed from the relentless busyness of the city.

name: Runyon Canyon Park
text:
Definitely recommend visiting here at sunset hour!

It‚Äôs not too far from Hollywood walk of fame. Around 20min walking. The vibes here are totally different from the busy Hollywood neighborhood. It can get a bit crowded for sure. But you‚Äôll also see more of local people coming here for a walk. If you take the path on the right after entering the park, you can get to the hillside where you can capture a good sight of Hollywood sign and Griffith Observatory. It might seem blurry form the pictures, but in real life they are definitely visible.

The sunset hour also makes the city view much more romantic. The sky would turn rosy. The temperature would also drop to a comfortable degree for hiking up and down the hills.

Prepare sneakers for sure. It can get quite steep. If not taking pictures, you can expect to finish the route in 1 hour if taking the loop facing Hollywood sign.

name: Runyon Canyon Park
text:
This park is the bomb! The views of the city are simply stunning, and of course, you can't miss that iconic Hollywood sign.

Now, let's talk about the trail. It's like a choose-your-own-adventure book, but instead of pages, you got two paths to pick from. Make sure you choose wisely, or you might end up in a real-life adventure ü§™

name: Runyon Canyon Park
text:
Quick easy hike up to a great view of the central LA region.
Parking along Fuller has a two hour limit, which is ideal for an easy paced hike through the main loop. The eastern trail up the hill is quicker to the view but a little more strenuous.
The western trail up and down towards the east will bring you to that view but will also provide that along your way back down (don't get distracted)
There is plenty of water provided throughout the trail, but there is almost no shade at all, so be ready for that.

name: Runyon Canyon Park
text: Came here on a Friday evening and it was quite sleepy and peaceful. Views were great and I did the trail going counter clockwise which is steep in the beginning but on the way down you can take the longer paved windy way.

name: Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve
text:
If I hadn't been enjoying San Diego so much already, Torrey Pines would have made it happen.

I thoroughly feel in love with this nature reserve. The beauty of the beach, the unique flora and Fauna, the scents and sounds... It was all perfectly beautiful and I can't wait to go back.

I think the only downside was the price of parking, but it was worth it to spend the day in such a stunning place.

name: Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve
text: We visited Torrey Pines for the first time and it didn't disappoint! If you get there in the morning, there is plenty of parking available. Parking is $15 from Monday - Thursday and $20 from Friday - Sunday. You may park at the bottom or drive a bit further up the hill, depending on which trails you'll be exploring. We opted for the trails further up the hill and I recommend them 100%, especially the Beach trail, yucca point and razor point. There are plenty of bathrooms by the parking lot, as well as water stations to refill your bottles.

name: Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve
text: Beautiful. Enough trails to spend many hours meaning and enjoying the scenery. There were a lot of people but there are so many different trail paths you could easily find yourself back in solitude moving on to a different path.

name: Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve
text: Awe inspiring views. Moderate trails. Beautiful beach. The line/wait to get in to the park was significant (on a Saturday in Sept). There is South Beach parking ($$), North Beach parking ($) and free parking (0) areas. We absolutely loved our time at Torrey Pines. Definitely recommend.

name: Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve
text: This was our first visit to the state reserve, and it‚Äôs a fantastic park right on the shore. There‚Äôs plenty of parking and easy access to hiking trails with scenic ocean views. You can also explore the local area. We spent half a day here, but honestly, I could have stayed all day!

name: Palmer Park Trailhead
text: My go to spot. Always a great place to take the üê∂ for a hike for sure. She loves it here as much or more than I do. So much to explore. Far better than flat ol boring walking trails. The trails are also great for mountain biking. More challenging than you might expect from a publicly frequented park in the middle of town.

name: Palmer Park Trailhead
text: A must do in Colorado Springs. Fantastic views of the city, beautiful flowering cacti and plants around June, and some awesome rock formations that you can explore. Lots of parking and super easy access for all. Dog friendly and parts of the trails are actually off leash.

name: Palmer Park Trailhead
text: Wonderful views. Great hiking. Plenty of trails.  5 stars if bathroom was unlocked!

name: Palmer Park Trailhead
text: Great playground at the front entrance.  Awesome trails for hiking.  You can do a good number of miles in this park in the middle of the city. Also great for Mt biking.

name: Palmer Park Trailhead
text: My boys loved it! Great for R/C rock crawlers.

name: Matthews / Winters Park
text: Nice local park with plenty of trails. Good view on the hills and be prepared to encounter some wildlife animals like deer. You can hike long and short, with a detailed map on the entrance. Also the trails are well marked and easy to follow. Definitely a good place for hiking, recommend.

name: Matthews / Winters Park
text: Beautiful trails that were well maintained and easy to locate.  Friendly hikers and their pets along the way!  Views were incredible!

name: Matthews / Winters Park
text: Did it all - top lot through the Cherry Gulch, Red Rocks Trail, Morrison Slide, big loop around 12k steps and 2 hrs in total with the puppers. Lots of dogs and people including mountain bikes on the trail. Very well maintained. Beware no water and very exposed throughout entire hike. Multiple places to stop and turn or complete smaller loops as desired. Bathroom facilities clean and no wait. Private with locks. Doggie doo bags available in the front of the hike. Great choice for the day.

name: Matthews / Winters Park
text: One of my favorite trails in Jefferson County. From the parking lot take the trail up, stay to the right on Red Rocks Trail which merges with Morrison Slide Trail and you‚Äôll climb up to the ‚Äúsummit.‚Äù Great views of the front range, early morning on most weekdays is generally the best time to do this loop. The loop back to the parking area takes about an hour and a half.

name: Matthews / Winters Park
text: Really nice hiking here. Trails are in very good shape (it‚Äôs October so everything is dry) A nice mix of uphill, downhill, some rock walking but most is dirt.  Go early though for parking. We were leaving at 9:30 and cars were waiting to take our space. There is a sign saying there was additional parking at _____.  Not sure where, but I did see a parking lot not too far down the road - but on the other side of the road.  It might be a bit tricky getting across. I have been once before this time, and would go back again.

name: Palmer Park Trail CaveOutlook
text: The whole park is a great place to go hiking... this little spot is nice to sit and enjoy the view...make sure you are hydrating, bring lots of water! It gets pretty hot...

name: Palmer Park Trail CaveOutlook
text:
Absolutely stunning views!! We are new to Colorado and hiking and although we were out of breath most of the hike, it was fairly easy physically, so I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs not too bad for beginners! We found 3 caves but you had to go off trail a little and climb down some rocks to see them, don‚Äôt worry it‚Äôs not any crazy rock climbing, I‚Äôm 41, not ‚ÄúFit‚Äù and I still made it, just make sure you have good shoes with good tread. Follow the Yucca Trail and The coordinates to the caves we found are :

name: Palmer Park Trail CaveOutlook
text:
Update: I came here for the second time to try to find the ‚Äúcave outlook‚Äù but could not find the trail to take me and my friend there. Again gorgeous views, peaceful and quiet. The trail does get fairly hot because there‚Äôs not a lot of shade and lots of rock. We followed the templeton trail off of the Eden trail and I would say it‚Äôs an intermediate to advanced hike as it was steep in some areas with some downhills as well. A handful of bicycles, trail runners, and hikers. Not suitable for strollers. With everything said, this is one of the most nature filled, most gorgeous hikes, with intermediate/advanced trail options in the Colorado Springs area.

Overall I do recommend and loved this hiking area :)

Original review: Absolutely beautiful! Took my weinie dogs for a hike and they loved it. I got stung by a wasp just walking on the trail so be careful.

The views were still incredible and I definitely recommend the trails here!

name: Palmer Park Trail CaveOutlook
text: This is such a gem spot as well all the other hidden gems in colorado springs.I suggest good shoes that don't slide on sand rocky paths.I tucked n roll not wearing the proper shoes so highly suggested for a safe hike.Perfect cliffs spot to overlook the city.As well as perfect spot for meditation and Journaling:)

name: Palmer Park Trail CaveOutlook
text: Just absolutely spectacular scrambling spots and hiking trails my dog has no problems going up the rocks and we've never been disappointed with the scenery!

name: Mount Falcon Park
text: My husband and I hiked here before going to a concert at red rocks. The multi use trail was well maintained and challenging with the elevation change. All trail users were respectful of each other and it was fun to see red rocks from a distance and then a further distance as we hiked along. Beautiful area, hot in July but totally doable. Had breakfast at the nice picnic area before heading out and bathrooms were some of the cleanest and well maintained that we had encountered.

name: Mount Falcon Park
text:
Quick and easy access from Denver. A whole network of trails, from wide and graveled trails to narrow and steep. City views and Continental Divide views are amazing.
Bathrooms, picnic shelters. Crowded on summer weekends.

name: Mount Falcon Park
text:
I really had a great time here. Trails are in good shape and wasn‚Äôt super crowded. We were there about 2 1/2 hours. Has some good trails for those that are looking to gain experience or are new like me. The views are so pretty and you can‚Äôt the noise from the city.
NOTE: trail was icy and snowy. I‚Äôd recommend spikes and most people I encountered in the trail had them on

name: Mount Falcon Park
text:
I've been.
Going there for 40 years.It is a beautiful place to go lots of history was going to be a presidential resort before I got hit by lightning the second time and burned down

name: Mount Falcon Park
text:
Mount Falcon is a very interesting place.   Once owned by one of Denver's elite business men.  The remains of John Walker's house are at the top of the trail.   As well as the start of the foundation to what was supposed to be the White House of the West.
Starting at the Morrison parking lot, the trail will become an 8 mile roundtrip out and back hike.  Excellent views are afforded all around.  To the East is denver and down below to the North is red rocks amphitheater.  Once you get high enough, there is a lot of other peaks to see.
The trail does get more rocky at the top.   Hikers and bikers will be sharing this trail. There is a lot of sun exposure.   Very nice trail though for 3 or so hours.

name: Ralston Creek Trail
text:
I biked the entirety of the trail (out and back) which was about 26 miles round trip.  There is a slight elevation gain of around 250 feet, so fairly level with a few steep inclines as you approach Tucker Lake and Blunn Reservoir.  The trail takes you through several, well maintained city parks and through a nice golf course.  There is also a very cool pedestrian bridge at the end of the trail located at Gold Strike Park.  The trail can be difficult to follow at times as it forces you to jump on the street for several blocks before you reconnect to the trail.  Keep an eye for signs directing back to the trail.

Overall, this was a nice ride.  It wasn't too busy which made social distancing very manageable.

name: Ralston Creek Trail
text: Ralston Creek Trail is a path that winds through some of the Denver Area metro suburbs. I usually get in the is at the Gold Strike Park off 56th & Ralston Road. It's a small park with a dirt lot, but there's plenty of traffic in and out which tells me it's a good place to park and walk the dog or go for a bike ride. I haven't gone very far in either direction on the trail, but it is very nice to walk/ride. The scenery compliments the creek running alongside, and the sound of traffic and other modern amenities did not interfere with the experience.

name: East Plum Creek Trail - Meadows Trailhead and Parking
text: I have regularly biked and walked on the East Plum Creek Trail for many years and really enjoy the scenery and wildlife I have seen, including: deer, beaver, snakes, coyotes, and a large assortment of birds. But today my focus was a little different. Recently, I read an article in the National Geographic about a photographer who takes pictures of tree bark from around the world. That gave me an idea. During my walk today on the East Plum Creek Trail I decided to see what the bark of various trees had to offer and was truly surprised by what I saw. All of the photos attached to this review were taken within a very short distance: less than 30 yards. Based on what I saw today, I intend for this to be an ongoing project.

name: Paradiset
text:
Paradiset Nature Reserve in Huddinge is a tranquil oasis and a gem for nature lovers. Located just a few miles south of Stockholm, this reserve offers a fantastic opportunity to get close to nature and enjoy its beauty.

One of the most impressive aspects of Paradiset is its varied landscape. Here you can find everything from enchanted forests with tall spruces and pines to open meadows and sparkling lakes. The numerous hiking trails, including part of the S√∂rmlandsleden, make the area an ideal place for long walks and outdoor adventures.

For those interested in flora and fauna, there is much to discover. The reserve is home to a rich variety of wildlife and plant life, and you may encounter everything from deer to rare orchids. Bird watchers will also appreciate the many bird species that thrive in the area.

Paradiset Nature Reserve also offers excellent opportunities for outdoor activities. There are several rest areas with barbecue facilities, making it easy to take a break and enjoy a picnic in the middle of nature. In winter, the area transforms into a winter paradise with opportunities for skiing and ice skating.

In summary, Paradiset Nature Reserve is a perfect destination for those seeking a nature experience without having to travel far from the city. With its scenic views, well-maintained hiking trails, and rich biodiversity, this reserve offers a welcome break from everyday life and a chance to truly relax and enjoy nature.

text: A quite large nature reserve for the placement surrounded by the city suburbs, most of it pine forest on shallow soils in the more elevated parts, with some trees several hundred years old. There are some non-native species here and there, like northern red oak and larch, probably spread from parks. Polypores, insect life, lichens, and more indicate high ecological values. Running trails and forest paths criss-cross the area so it's all quite accessible. Several huge erratic boulders are spread across the area, one of many clearly visible features of the last deglaciation.

text:
My absolute favourite place in Stockholm! The views from the top of the hill are simply breathtaking, whether you visit during the day or at night. However I would caution that it can be a bit difficult to navigate the park at night as the lighting is not very bright.

One thing to keep in mind is that the park can get quite busy, especially during peak times. The top of the hill doesn‚Äôt have much room, so it can feel a bit crowded at times. However, in my opinion, the stunning panoramic views more than make up for any potential crowds.

If you have mobility issues, I would suggest being careful as the park is quite rocky and can be very slippery in winter. Whilst it is accessible to some degree, it may not be the best option for everyone.

I highly recommend Skinnarviksparken for anyone visiting Stockholm. It‚Äôs a beautiful, serene escape from the hustle of the city, and the views are simply unforgettable.
